also i can t even look nobody in the eye because of it wtf do i do it s ruining the relationship i have with my family and parent it s just pissing me tf off i went to get a haircut today but walked tf out because i wa too anxious and my anxiety wa high so when i walked in i sat all the way in the back so my barber and other people wouldn t see me because of my dumbass anxiety but how else wa i gon na get a cut if he couldn t see me right so like i said i just walked tf out with my head down n cried when i got home

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you're feeling overwhelmed by your anxiety and it's impacting various aspects of your life, including your relationships and daily activities. It's important to acknowledge that your feelings are valid and that anxiety is a common experience for many people. However, it's also crucial to recognize that your anxiety is not a reflection of your worth or ability to cope with challenges.

One approach we could explore is practicing exposure therapy, which involves gradually exposing yourself to the situations or triggers that cause you anxiety in a controlled and supportive environment. This can help desensitize you to the anxiety-provoking stimuli and build up your resilience over time. For example, you could start by visiting your barber at the same time each week and gradually work your way up to sitting in a less secluded area.

Another strategy that may be helpful is cognitive restructuring, which involves challenging and reframing negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to your anxiety. For instance, instead of thinking "if I don't get a haircut, I'll be a failure," you could reframe it as "getting a haircut is important for my self-care and overall well-being, but it's okay if I can't do it right now due to my anxiety."

Additionally, we could explore relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation to help manage your anxiety in the moment. These practices can help calm your mind and body, reducing the physical symptoms of anxiety and making it easier to engage in situations that might otherwise be challenging.

It's important to remember that progress in therapy is not always a linear process, and setbacks are a normal part of the journey. Be patient with yourself and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way. Remember, you're not alone in this, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's not uncommon for people to question the meaning and purpose of their lives, especially during challenging times. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences and perspectives are unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, I can offer some general suggestions and guidance that may be helpful for you.

First, it's essential to prioritize self-care. This can include getting enough restful sleep, eating a balanced diet, engaging in regular physical activity, and practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation. Taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental and emotional well-being.

Second, consider reaching out to a mental health professional for support and guidance. They can provide a safe and confidential space for you to explore your feelings and develop coping strategies. They can also help you identify any underlying issues that may be contributing to your current situation.

Third, try to engage in activities that bring you joy and a sense of accomplishment. This could be hobbies, creative pursuits, or volunteering. Engaging in activities that give you a sense of purpose can help improve your mood and motivation.

Fourth, consider connecting with a support group or community of people who have gone through similar experiences. Sharing your story and hearing from others can provide a sense of validation and understanding.

Lastly, it's essential to remember that healing is a process, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. Be gentle with yourself and acknowledge that progress may not always be linear. Remember that you're not alone in your struggles, and there are resources and people out there who can help you.

[Question]
i am year old and i finallly came to the conclusion that i need help with anxiety i signed up for therapy and will have my first session in a couple of day prior to the therapy session i met with a prescriber to discus medication they recomended starting me off on zoloft or lexapro in general i tend to think of medication a a last resort not just for thing like this but in all aspect for example i rarely used medinces perscribed to me for pain after surgery and would only use them if absolutely necesarry i don t even like taking ibuprofen for a headache unless it is unbearable given that i am trying to figure out whether or going on anxiety medication is necessary for me or not i am worried about going on something for the rest of my life and am a little concerned about the side effect on the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also if anyone ha any thought on whether or not someone that is new to this whole anexiety improvement journey should jump into med or just try therapy first and see how that go i always kind of ignored my anxiety and told myself that since i have been able to graduate from college with a good degree hold down a great job for several year and maintain good relationship that my anxiety must not be that bad but a time go by i am starting to feel like it is getting worse and is negatively impacting my happiness and is leading my to lean on stimulant and alcohol too much which doesn t seem like a long term healthy way of handling this i have also had a couple of concussion in the last few year so i am not sure how much that play into what i am going through i would really appreciate it if some people could speak to their experience or have any encouragement or advice for someone just starting out in therapy and potentially medication please reach out if i can add additional context to my situation to help clarity where i am at also i wa reading some other post on this sub about people being tired all of the time i have spent year trying to figure out medically why to no avail i am starting to wondering if my axiety is causing it can anyone speak to any experience or epiphany they have had with this thanks garrison

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've taken the step to seek help for your anxiety, Garrison. I understand that the decision to start medication is a personal one, and it's common to have concerns about long-term use and potential side effects. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with medication is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another.

In terms of your question about whether someone new to the anxiety improvement journey should jump into medication or just try therapy first, it's essential to consider your individual needs and circumstances. Therapy can be an effective way to learn coping skills and strategies for managing anxiety, and it's a more holistic approach that focuses on addressing the root causes of your anxiety. However, medication can provide additional support and help manage symptoms that may be interfering with your daily life.

It's also worth noting that therapy and medication are not mutually exclusive. Many people find that a combination of therapy and medication is the most effective approach for managing their anxiety. It's important to have an open and honest conversation with your therapist and prescriber about your concerns and goals, as they can help guide you in making the best decision for your situation.

Regarding your experience with pain medication after surgery, it's essential to recognize that everyone's pain tolerance and response to medication is different. Your reluctance to use medication as a last resort is a valid concern, but it's important to remember that anxiety medication is not the same as pain medication. Anxiety medication is designed to help manage symptoms of anxiety and depression, and it can be an essential tool in helping you regain control of your life and improve your overall well-being.

Your history of concussions may indeed play a role in your current situation, and it's essential to discuss this with your therapist and prescriber. Traumatic brain injuries can contribute to anxiety and other mental health conditions, and it's crucial to address any potential connections between your injuries and your symptoms.

Lastly, I'd like to encourage you to reach out to your support system, such as friends and family, as they can provide additional emotional support and understanding during this journey. Remember, you're not alone, and there are many resources available to help you along the way.

I hope this information is helpful, and I'm here to support you in any way I can. If you have any
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i come from a pretty african evangelical household where mental health wasn t talked about or addressed growing up in the last few year i ve noticed intense wave of sadness and internal pain turn from short stint of time to practically everyday now there will be time period of elation but for the most part my disposition ha remained sad on an almost daily basis i feel anger irritability deep sadness about the way thing haven t worked out for me in the past or currently or intense rejection from others who may not intend their action to be rejection for example the housemate i live with are a married couple who i wa in their wedding so we re all friend when i first moved in they would always have dinner with me asking me what i wanted to eat for dinner but that ha tapered off and tonight i walked in from work late and saw they had dinner together and were enjoying tv it broke me and i went to my room feeling intense inner pain this stuff is so new to me i have no clue how to continue through life because nobody know i struggle with this i don t even know where to begin to share with others or begin to understand what help i need any advice would be much appreciated

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can imagine that growing up in an African Evangelical household where mental health wasn't talked about or addressed, you may have felt a lack of support and understanding when it comes to your emotional well-being. It's understandable that you've noticed an intense wave of sadness and internal pain that has become a regular part of your life. The fact that there are periods of elation is a positive sign, but it's important to address the underlying causes of your sadness.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the deep sadness, anger, and irritability you're experiencing. These emotions are valid, and it's essential to give yourself permission to feel them. It's not uncommon for people to experience rejection or feel left out, especially when they perceive actions as intentional, even if that wasn't the intention. In this case, the tapering off of the dinners and the feeling of being broken when you saw the married couple enjoying their time together triggered intense inner pain.

Given the newness of these feelings for you, it's natural to feel overwhelmed and unsure of how to navigate them. Sharing your struggles with others can be a crucial step towards understanding and seeking help. You mentioned that you have friends who are married and were once close with you. Consider reaching out to them and expressing your feelings openly. They may provide valuable support and understanding.

Additionally, seeking professional help from a mental health expert can be beneficial. They can offer guidance tailored to your specific situation and provide you with coping strategies and tools to manage your emotions. A therapist can help you explore the root causes of your sadness and develop a plan to address them.

In the meantime, there are some self-care practices you can try to support your emotional well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or exercise, can help lift your mood. Practicing mindfulness or meditation can also be helpful in managing emotions and reducing stress.

Remember, it's essential to be patient with yourself during this process. Healing takes time, and it's okay to take small steps towards understanding and supporting your own mental health. You've taken the first step by reaching out for advice, and I believe that with support and self-care, you can find ways to navigate through life's challenges and find inner peace.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It sounds like you're experiencing a significant amount of distress due to these anxiety attacks that occur during conversations. It's important to acknowledge that these feelings are valid and that you're not alone in experiencing them. It might be beneficial to challenge these thoughts by asking yourself if there is any evidence supporting the assumption that you are hiding something. Often, our minds can create scenarios that aren't based in reality, and it's essential to remind yourself of this.

Additionally, practicing self-compassion can be beneficial. Remember that everyone has preferences and opinions, and it's okay to express them without fear of judgment. Remind yourself that you are not defined by these preferences or any other aspect of your identity.

In terms of managing the physical symptoms of anxiety attacks, deep breathing exercises can be helpful. When you feel the anxiety rising, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help regulate your heart rate and bring a sense of calmness to your body.

It may also be beneficial to engage in activities that promote relaxation and reduce stress. This could include hobbies, exercise, meditation, or spending time in nature. Finding healthy outlets for stress can help alleviate some of the anxiety you experience during conversations.

Lastly, consider seeking support from trusted friends or loved ones. Sharing your experiences with someone you trust can provide validation and understanding. They may also offer different perspectives or coping strategies that have worked for them.

Remember, these suggestions are not a substitute for professional help, but they can serve as a starting point in managing your anxiety. If your symptoms persist or worsen, it may be beneficial to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's been a while since you've shared your experiences with anxiety and the challenges you've faced in managing it. I appreciate your openness and willingness to seek support. It's important to acknowledge that everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, I can offer some general suggestions and guidance based on common strategies used in mental health.

Firstly, I encourage you to continue working closely with your healthcare provider. They can help assess your current treatment plan, adjust dosages if necessary, and explore alternative options. Open communication with your provider is crucial in ensuring that you receive the best possible care for your specific needs.

In addition to medication, there are several evidence-based therapies that have shown effectiveness in managing anxiety. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is one such approach. CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and replacing them with more balanced and realistic ones. This can help reduce anxiety by changing the way we think and respond to stressful situations.

Another helpful technique is deep breathing exercises. When we experience anxiety, our body's stress response is activated, leading to rapid breathing and increased tension. Deep breathing exercises can help calm the body and mind by slowing down our heart rate and promoting relaxation. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose for a count of four, holding your breath for a count of four, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth for a count of six. Repeat this several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

Engaging in regular physical activity can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood-boosting chemicals in the brain. It can help reduce stress, improve sleep quality, and increase overall well-being. Finding an activity that you enjoy, whether it's going for a walk, practicing yoga, or participating in a sport, can make it easier to incorporate exercise into your routine.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore mindfulness practices. Mindfulness involves focusing your attention on the present moment without judgment. This can help redirect your thoughts away from anxious patterns and bring a sense of calm. There are various resources available, such as guided meditation apps or online videos, that can guide you through mindfulness exercises.

Lastly, building a support network can provide invaluable emotional support. Connecting with others who have experienced similar challenges can

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 it sounds like you're experiencing a great deal of anxiety and fear, and it's understandable that these thoughts are overwhelming for you. it's important to remember that while these worries are valid, they may not always reflect reality. it's essential to take a step back and consider the likelihood of these fears coming true. for example, the chances of being shot in school or your sister being kidnapped are extremely low. while it's natural to worry about the safety and well-being of yourself and your loved ones, it's crucial to balance these concerns with the present moment and the things that you can control.

one effective coping strategy for managing anxiety is practicing mindfulness. this involves focusing on the present moment and letting go of worries about the future or the past. deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization techniques are all helpful practices that can help you ground yourself in the present.

another approach is cognitive restructuring, which involves challenging negative thought patterns and replacing them with more balanced and realistic ones. for example, instead of catastrophizing a situation, you can try to identify the evidence for and against your fears, and consider alternative explanations for what might be happening.

it's also essential to prioritize self-care and engage in activities that bring you joy and help you relax. this can include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or connecting with supportive friends and family.

lastly, if your anxiety is significantly impacting your daily life and causing significant distress, it may be helpful to consider seeking professional help from a mental health professional. they can provide you with additional tools and support to manage your anxiety and help you develop a personalized treatment plan.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

In your case, it seems that your guilt is rooted in both your own experiences and the expectations you have of yourself. You feel guilty for burdening others with your own problems, even though you may be dealing with challenges that are just as significant. At the same time, you feel guilty for being unable to handle the problems of others, which leaves you feeling exhausted and helpless. It's essential to recognize that these feelings are not unique to you, and that many people struggle with similar emotions. However, it's also crucial to prioritize your own well-being and seek out healthy ways to manage your guilt and stress. This might include setting boundaries with others, practicing self-care, and seeking support from trusted friends, family, or mental health professionals. It's important to remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it, and that taking care of yourself is not a selfish act, but rather an essential part of maintaining your overall health and well-being. Additionally, it may be helpful to explore the underlying causes of your guilt and work to address any underlying emotional or psychological triggers that may be contributing to these feelings. [Question]
i just can t seem to relax throughout the day every time i think about sitting down and reading watching a tv show meditating putting a face mask on etc i ve got 000 thing on my mind random stuff anxious thought thing i have to get done etcetc so i never get to truly relax i panic just thinking about reading cause it ll be calm and there s nothing to distract me from my thought until i m able to focus on the book which can take a while the only time i m able to actively relax is when i m tired after i ve worked out for h in the gym or late at night got ta find the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep feel like walking a tightrope amp even when i manage to get there i have more important stuff to do than relaxing eg studying amp other stuff that my anxious self didn t manage to do

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 it sounds like you're experiencing a significant amount of anxiety throughout the day, which is preventing you from fully relaxing and engaging in activities that promote relaxation. it's important to acknowledge that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. however, i can offer some general suggestions that may be helpful for managing anxiety and finding moments of relaxation in your day.

first, it's essential to prioritize self-care and make time for activities that bring you joy and help you relax. this could include reading, watching a tv show, taking a warm bath, or engaging in a hobby that you enjoy. it's crucial to recognize that these activities are not a luxury, but rather an essential part of maintaining good mental and emotional health.

second, it may be helpful to try incorporating mindfulness practices into your day. mindfulness is the practice of being fully present in the moment, without judgment. it can help reduce anxiety and promote relaxation. this could include practicing deep breathing exercises, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation. these techniques can be done in short bursts throughout the day, even during moments of high anxiety.

third, it's essential to find a balance between being productive and taking time for yourself. it's common for people with anxiety to feel like they always have more to do, but it's crucial to recognize that taking time for relaxation and self-care is not only important for your mental health, but also for your physical health and overall well-being. it may be helpful to schedule relaxation time into your day, just as you would schedule time for work or other commitments.

lastly, it's essential to remember that managing anxiety is a process, and it's okay to have setbacks. it's important to be kind to yourself and recognize that progress is not always linear. if you find that you're struggling to manage your anxiety on your own, it may be helpful to consider seeking support from a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and strategies tailored to your specific needs.

i hope these suggestions are helpful, and i encourage you to experiment with different strategies to find what works best for you. remember, the goal is not to eliminate anxiety entirely, but rather to find ways to manage it effectively and create moments of relaxation and self-care in your day.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i miss my life before this depressive episode idk if you can even call it an episode anymore it s been over year i don t think i ll ever be the same and that destroys me inside i miss 0 9 and 0 0 up until september i wa truly happy and just coasting through life so content i wa so happy and life wa so simple especially during the 0 0 lockdown all i had to do during the lockdown wa watch load of anime and random netflix show explore new music stay up all night and do nothing i even had time to explore my childlike side by doing load of painting and drawing using kiddie paint and colouring book my mental health wa great too i had no eating disorder no depression no school work my anxiety and ocd wa minimal and i wasn t so deeply lonely like i am now i can literally just hear a song smell a smell or taste a good that i experienced to during that period and i will burst out in tear because i miss not being depressed so much now even if i do try and enjoy life like i did back then and be carefree it ll never be the same because my anxiety and depression have quite literally destroyed me from the inside now i ll never be able to enjoy life like that again i had never been in a relationship and that didn t bother me at all now i ve still never been in a relationship and it make me feel unloveable and ugly i always hear people at school talking about their relationship and date and stuff and even though i don t want a boyfriend that bad i still feel like i m missing out on a key part of the teenage experience but still to be honest i m not that keen on a relationship i really just want to be happy anyway all that s left to do is die i have my plan in place and i have a date and method at least i can say that i experienced true happiness and one point in my life i guess

I want to assure you that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people experience periods of depression and anxiety, and it's possible to find ways to manage and cope with these feelings. [Question]
hi i am male i used to have a very emotional side but for the last year or so i am not able to feel sad especially for others sympathy i used to cry when my best friend cried to me about her break up but now i couldn t shed a single tear during my grandfather death i hated the feeling did i stop loving my grandfather even then why didn t i feel sad when i saw my mother cry she is the first person i don t want to see cry off late i feel it s affecting my friendship a well just to be clear it s not a overall numbness i still feel happiness anger and other emotion but this is really frustrating especially when i am getting into a relationship for the first time in my life i keep questioning my love for people i keep asking myself if i can t feel sad for them do i really love them

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and confused about your emotional experience, especially since you used to have a strong emotional side. It's important to remember that emotions can fluctuate and change over time, and there could be various reasons behind your current emotional state.

Firstly, it's essential to acknowledge that the inability to feel sad for others doesn't necessarily mean that you don't love them. Emotions are complex and multifaceted, and love can manifest in various ways beyond just feeling sad. It's also worth considering that your emotional response to others might be influenced by your own emotional well-being and any underlying issues you may be dealing with.

Given your recent relationship, it's natural to question your feelings and love for people. It might be helpful to reflect on what love means to you and what emotions you associate with love. Love can encompass a range of emotions, including happiness, affection, companionship, and even a sense of responsibility towards the well-being of the other person.

If you're concerned about your emotional ability to care for someone, it might be beneficial to explore this further with a mental health professional. They can help you identify any underlying emotional or psychological factors that may be contributing to your current emotional state. Additionally, they can provide you with tools and strategies to help you better understand and manage your emotions.

In the meantime, it's essential to practice self-compassion and not judge yourself based on your emotional response to others. Remember that emotions are complex and can be influenced by various factors. It's also important to consider that your emotional experience might be different from others, and that's okay.

Lastly, it's crucial to maintain open communication with your loved ones about your feelings and concerns. Sharing your thoughts and emotions can help deepen your connection and understanding of each other. It might also be helpful to engage in activities that allow you to express your emotions in a healthy and safe way, such as writing in a journal, engaging in creative pursuits, or practicing mindfulness and relaxation techniques.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

all the title are relateable but all the comment are like same life suck i m currently writing my note this is just another stop before the end though i seriously doubt there is anything that can be done i ve tried every medical treatment available including experimental one been through so much therapy and i m getting nowhere there is no beating this depression and on paper i have the perfect life great job loving partner supportive parent people would kill for this life and for me it s not enough the problem is me always been me which is why nobody outside can help you can t fix what is working a intended so yeah nobody is here to actually prevent so i guess that s another note they could find after i m done

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you're feeling frustrated and helpless in the face of your depression, despite having tried various treatments and therapies. It's understandable that you're feeling like there's no hope for improvement, especially when it seems like you have everything going for you in terms of your external circumstances. However, it's essential to remember that depression is a complex condition that often involves both biological and psychological factors. While it's true that you can't change certain aspects of your situation, such as your past experiences or family dynamics, there are still things that can be done to help you cope and find relief.

One approach that might be helpful is to focus on building resilience and finding ways to manage the challenges that come with depression. This could involve learning new coping skills, such as mindfulness meditation or cognitive restructuring, as well as engaging in activities that bring you joy and a sense of accomplishment. It's also important to remember that healing from depression is a process that takes time and effort, and that setbacks and challenges are a normal part of the journey.

Another approach might be to explore the role of your thoughts and beliefs in maintaining your depression. It's common for people with depression to have negative thought patterns that can exacerbate their feelings of hopelessness and helplessness. By learning to challenge these thoughts and replace them with more balanced and realistic ones, you may be able to shift your perspective and improve your mood.

Ultimately, the goal is to help you find ways to live a fulfilling and meaningful life despite your depression. This might involve setting small, achievable goals, practicing self-compassion, and reaching out for support from loved ones or a mental health professional. Remember, you're not alone in this, and there are resources available to help you on your journey towards healing.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it, and taking care of your mental health is just as important as taking care of your physical health.

[Question]
i m talking to my psych on monday and i want to do some research into what might work for me i have frequent mild panic attack infrequent but still kind of like once a week once every week severe panic attack and constant anxiety i ve tried a bunch of anxiety med but haven t really found any that worked for me however i haven t tried any in year so there s a chance i ve grown a i wa about during most of my trial and it s been a good year since then so what are were your favorite thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're taking the initiative to research different strategies and techniques for managing your anxiety and panic attacks. I understand that you've had some experience with anxiety medication in the past, but haven't found one that works well for you. It's important to remember that everyone's response to medication can vary, and it's worth exploring other options as well.

In addition to medication, there are several evidence-based therapies that have been effective for many people with anxiety and panic disorders. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is one such approach that can help you identify and challenge negative thought patterns and beliefs that contribute to your anxiety. It can also help you develop coping skills and strategies for managing panic attacks and reducing overall anxiety.

Another approach that may be helpful is mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), which involves practicing mindfulness meditation and other mindfulness techniques to help you become more aware of your thoughts and feelings and learn to respond to them in a more adaptive way.

Exercise, such as regular walking or jogging, has also been shown to be beneficial for reducing anxiety and improving mood. Additionally, relaxation techniques like deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization can help you manage anxiety in the moment.

It's important to remember that what works for one person may not work for another, so it may take some trial and error to find the strategies that resonate with you. I would encourage you to discuss these options with your psychologist on Monday, as they can provide you with more personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
it s been so long i have been avoiding to get treated especially because it s social anxiety i definitely don t want to talk to a stranger but it s been ruining my life so here we are any tip anything i should prepare what question do they ask you i am already getting anxiety attack because of the appointment

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can understand that the thought of going to a mental health appointment can be intimidating, especially if you're dealing with social anxiety. It's important to remember that mental health professionals are trained to provide a safe and supportive environment for you, and that they're there to help you, not judge you.

Preparing for your appointment can help alleviate some of the anxiety. Here are some suggestions:

1. Take some time to reflect on what you'd like to discuss during the appointment. Consider writing down your thoughts or making a list of specific concerns or questions you have. This can help ensure that you cover the most important topics during your session.
2. It might be helpful to practice some relaxation techniques before your appointment, such as deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation. These can help calm your mind and body and reduce anxiety.
3. Consider bringing a trusted friend or family member with you to the appointment. Having someone there for support can make the experience less daunting. Just let the mental health professional know in advance so they can make any necessary accommodations.
4. Remember that mental health professionals are bound by confidentiality, which means that what you share during the session will be kept private. This can help alleviate concerns about judgment or disclosure.
5. During the appointment, the mental health professional may ask questions about your personal history, current symptoms, and any challenges you're facing. They may also observe your behavior and ask for your thoughts and feelings on various topics. The goal is to gain a better understanding of your situation and help develop a treatment plan tailored to your needs.
6. It's important to remember that mental health appointments are a safe space for you to express yourself openly and honestly. The mental health professional is there to support you and provide guidance, not to judge you.

I hope these suggestions help make your appointment experience less anxiety-provoking. Remember, taking the step to seek help is a brave and important one, and I'm here to support you throughout this process.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling desperate and seeking advice for your extreme night sweats, which have been affecting your sleep and causing significant distress. While I'm not a medical professional, I can offer some suggestions and guidance based on common experiences and self-care strategies.

1. Keep a sleep diary: Start by keeping track of when the night sweats occur and any other relevant information such as what you ate or drank before bed, your level of stress, and any other symptoms you may be experiencing. This can help identify potential triggers or patterns.

2. Create a bedtime routine: Establishing a consistent routine before bed can help promote better sleep. Consider activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation.

3. Avoid stimulating substances: Avoid consuming caffeine, nicotine, and alcohol close to bedtime, as they can disrupt your sleep and contribute to night sweats.

4. Manage stress: High levels of stress can exacerbate anxiety and trigger night sweats. Explore stress management techniques that work for you, such as exercise, journaling, or talking to a trusted friend or family member.

5. Cool your bedroom: Keeping your bedroom cool can help regulate your body temperature and reduce night sweats. Use a fan or air conditioning if necessary, and consider using light bedding or pajamas made of breathable materials.

6. Consider natural remedies: Some people find that certain natural supplements or herbs, such as magnesium, valerian root, or chamomile, can help promote relaxation and improve sleep quality. However, it's important to consult with a healthcare professional before trying any new supplements.

7. Discuss with your psychiatrist: Since you've already been working with a psychiatrist, it may be helpful to discuss your night sweats during your next appointment. They may be able to provide additional guidance or adjust your medication if necessary.

8. Seek support from others: Connecting with others who have similar experiences can be comforting and helpful. Consider joining a support group or seeking out online communities where you can share your experiences and learn from others.

Remember, while these suggestions may be helpful for many people, it's important to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice based on your specific situation. They will be
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

guy do any of you also wake up every morning from scary nightmare and feeling completely estranged when you open your eye like your surrounding feel so foreign eventho it s your own home your own room and it take some time for you to realize youre just fine do you wake up with fear every morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's essential to remember that these feelings are temporary and that you're in a safe and familiar environment.

One approach to managing these feelings could be to practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, before going to bed. These techniques can help calm your mind and body, making it easier for you to fall asleep and reducing the likelihood of waking up from a nightmare feeling disoriented and fearful.

Another strategy could be to maintain a consistent bedtime routine. This routine can help signal to your body that it's time to relax and prepare for sleep. This might include activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing gentle stretches.

It's also important to consider any underlying emotional or psychological factors that might be contributing to these feelings. If these feelings persist or become more frequent, it might be helpful to explore them further with a mental health professional. They can provide you with additional strategies and support to help manage your anxiety and improve your overall sleep quality.

Remember, it's essential to be gentle with yourself and acknowledge that these feelings are a normal part of the human experience. By taking steps to manage your anxiety and improve your sleep hygiene, you can help reduce the frequency and intensity of these feelings.

[Question]
i really need a diagnosis my body hurt sometimes not in a pain way but like a close relative ha died my heart sink my hand shake but it s over a very minor thing my head is saying everything is fine logical but my body feel horrible like i want to burst into tear i d rather physical pain than this i ve broken my finger punching stuff just to snap out of it which work but the best way is for someone to tell me i m wrong tell me that i m thinking stupidly but it s ok and that everything is alright and then it go away this ha happened for a couple year now and i hate it and i need some help it s happening a i write this and i have no one to talk to to feel alright and my head went straight to punching something so i can feel alright again but i know i shouldn t do that i d really appreciate some help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a complex emotional and physical response to your thoughts and feelings. It's important to acknowledge that your experiences are valid, and that your body's reactions are a natural response to the emotional turmoil you're experiencing. I understand that you've been dealing with this for a couple of years now, and it's causing significant distress.

One approach that might be helpful for you is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT is a type of psychotherapy that focuses on helping individuals identify and challenge negative thought patterns and replace them with more balanced, realistic thoughts. In your case, it seems like your mind and body are reacting strongly to certain thoughts, and CBT could help you develop more adaptive ways of thinking and responding to these thoughts.

Another approach that might be beneficial for you is mindfulness meditation. Mindfulness meditation can help you become more aware of your thoughts and emotions without judgment, which could help you develop a greater sense of control over your reactions. This might be particularly helpful for you when you're feeling overwhelmed by your thoughts and your body's responses.

It's also essential to consider the role of self-harm in your coping mechanisms. While it may provide temporary relief, it's important to explore alternative ways of managing your emotions that are healthier and safer. This could include engaging in physical activity, practicing relaxation techniques, or reaching out to supportive friends or family members.

Lastly, it's crucial to remember that you're not alone in this. Many people experience similar emotional and physical responses to their thoughts and feelings, and seeking professional help can provide you with the tools and support you need to manage these experiences more effectively. I encourage you to reach out to a mental health professional who can work with you to develop a personalized treatment plan that addresses your unique needs and circumstances.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have gad and have been going through an emotional upheaval with my partner causing extra stress i ve been reducing my lexapro slightly a i felt it wa not working but now am more anxious than ever despite tiny change today i woke up full of dread to go to work no reason i love my job but it all felt too much a a mid ground i decided to work from home today instead of going in i still feel light headed and awful and have the added guilt of messing client around by changing the schedule or converting to online service what do i do how do i get myself to work when it all feel too much

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you're dealing with a complex situation where your anxiety is impacting your ability to attend work, and you're feeling guilty about the potential consequences of changing your schedule. It's important to acknowledge that your anxiety is a valid concern, and it's essential to prioritize your mental health. In this situation, I would suggest considering a few strategies to help you navigate this challenge.

First, it's crucial to communicate openly with your employer about your situation. They may be able to offer flexible solutions, such as working from home or adjusting your work schedule to accommodate your anxiety. This open communication can help alleviate some of the guilt you're feeling about changing the schedule.

Second, it's essential to consider the short-term and long-term consequences of your actions. In the short-term, working from home today may help you manage your anxiety and avoid the added stress of going into work. However, it's essential to consider the long-term implications of this decision. Will working from home become a regular occurrence, and how will that impact your professional growth and relationships with your colleagues?

Lastly, it's important to focus on self-care and managing your anxiety. This may involve practicing relaxation techniques, engaging in activities that bring you joy, or seeking support from friends, family, or a mental health professional. By prioritizing your self-care, you'll be better equipped to handle the challenges that come your way.

In summary, I encourage you to communicate openly with your employer, consider the short-term and long-term consequences of your decisions, and focus on self-care to manage your anxiety. Remember, it's essential to prioritize your mental health, and I'm here to support you in any way I can.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
in high school i wa quiet mind my business didn t talk to many people i noticed that certain people just didn t like me one time a teacher moved a girl to sit next to me and she made this weird face like annoyed and when she sat next to me she wa slightly turned ti the direction i wasn t in and not facing straight another occasion i wa sitting in a table with other people and none of them would bother to talk to me even when i tried to make a convo or ask a question and one of them actually cut hair now and my brother and dad cut their hair with her and they re always saying she talk a lot etc she s friendly today i went to that place to cut my hair and she wa completely quiet just asked me what hair type i wanted and the price of the cut i didn t want to start a convo cause i knew that back then she wouldn t even want to talk i just feel like i have something that just make people dislike me for no reason

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's clear that you've experienced a pattern of feeling disliked by certain individuals, especially in high school. These experiences have left you feeling confused and wondering why this might be happening. It's important to acknowledge that people's preferences and behaviors can be complex and multifaceted, and it's not always possible to pinpoint a single reason for why someone might not want to engage with us. However, it's also essential to recognize that our own perceptions and interpretations of these situations can influence how we feel about them.

In the context of counseling psychology, this is known as the cognitive appraisal theory, which suggests that our thoughts and emotions are shaped by how we interpret and make sense of the situations we encounter. In your case, you've interpreted these experiences as evidence that there's something about you that makes people dislike you. This belief, known as a negative self-schema, can lead to feelings of low self-worth and self-blame.

To challenge this negative self-schema, it's helpful to consider alternative explanations for the behaviors of others. For instance, the girl who made a face when she sat next to you might have had her own reasons for her behavior that had nothing to do with you. Similarly, the group of people who didn't engage with you during lunch might have been preoccupied with their own concerns.

Moreover, it's essential to focus on the present and the people who do value and appreciate you for who you are. Building and nurturing these relationships can help counteract the negative experiences from your past. Additionally, practicing self-compassion and self-care can help you develop a more positive self-image and reduce feelings of self-blame.

In summary, while it's natural to feel frustrated and confused when we encounter people who seem to dislike us, it's crucial to avoid making sweeping generalizations about ourselves based on these experiences. Instead, we can challenge our negative self-schemas by considering alternative explanations for others' behaviors and focusing on the present and the people who value us.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 I can see that you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling to find the motivation to do things that used to bring you joy. It's important to acknowledge that losing interest in things we once enjoyed can be a common experience, especially during times of stress or emotional distress. However, it's essential to recognize that there may be underlying factors contributing to your current situation.

One approach we could explore is the concept of "anhedonia," which refers to the inability to experience pleasure or joy, even from activities that were once enjoyable. Anhedonia can be a symptom of various mental health conditions, such as depression or anxiety. It's essential to consider the possibility that there may be underlying emotional or psychological factors contributing to your current experience.

Additionally, it's important to address the self-critical thoughts and beliefs that you're holding onto. It's natural to have negative thoughts about ourselves, but it's crucial to challenge these thoughts and consider alternative perspectives. This can help us develop a more compassionate and understanding relationship with ourselves, which can be a powerful motivator for change.

In terms of finding help, it's essential to remember that seeking support is a sign of strength, not weakness. There are many resources available, such as therapy, support groups, and self-help materials, that can provide valuable guidance and support during this time. It's essential to prioritize your mental and emotional well-being, as this will ultimately help you navigate the challenges you're facing and find the motivation to move forward.

It's also important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and there's no one-size-fits-all solution. It may take time and effort to find the strategies and resources that work best for you. [Question]
hey everyone i am just curious if anyone ha also suffered from this type of anxiety i will get anxiety and panic about one thing and after coping and learning to overcome this anxiety my anxiety tends to hyper fixate on something else to worry about im wondering if anyone else ha dealt with this and how they stopped this cycle im currently on sertraline and buspirone and attend therapy a well for anxiety and panic disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and seeking support from others who may have experienced similar challenges. The phenomenon you described, where anxiety and panic shift from one focus to another, is a common experience for many individuals dealing with anxiety and panic disorders. It's important to remember that everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some strategies and techniques that have been helpful for many people in managing their anxiety.

One approach that may be beneficial is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and beliefs that contribute to anxiety. By learning to recognize and challenge these thoughts, you can develop more balanced and realistic ways of thinking. This can help reduce the intensity and frequency of anxiety episodes.

Another technique that may be helpful is mindfulness meditation. Mindfulness practices can help you become more aware of your thoughts and emotions without judgment. By practicing mindfulness regularly, you can learn to observe your anxious thoughts as passing mental events rather than objective realities. This can help reduce the emotional impact of your anxiety and make it easier to let go of specific worries.

In addition to these therapeutic approaches, self-care practices can also play a crucial role in managing anxiety. Engaging in regular physical exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, getting enough sleep, and practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation can all contribute to reducing anxiety symptoms.

It's also important to remember that healing from anxiety is a process that takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. Remember that setbacks are a normal part of the journey, and it's okay to ask for support when you need it.

While I'm not a mental health professional, I hope these suggestions provide you with some ideas to explore. It may be helpful to discuss these strategies with your therapist or prescribing physician to determine if they're appropriate for your specific situation.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i stood up for myself about not being credited for artwork used by my school and now somehow that ha lead to a teacher talking about me to my peer behind my back and me being harassed by a woman who work for the school on their drama production i contacted my principal and he ha not responded my mom say if i go to anyone higher up i will get in trouble i feel trapped everyone hate me now and the rest of my school year is going to be horrible i feel like the only way to fix this situation is to die i fucked everything up

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and frustrated by the recent events that have unfolded at your school. It's understandable that you're feeling a range of emotions, including anger, sadness, and hopelessness. The situation with the artwork credit and the subsequent backlash from the teacher and the woman working on the drama production has left you feeling helpless and trapped. It's important to acknowledge that these feelings are valid and that you've been through a challenging experience. However, it's crucial to remember that there are still resources available to you and that there are steps you can take to address the situation.

First, it's essential to prioritize your safety and well-being. If you're feeling suicidal or having thoughts of self-harm, it's important to reach out to a trusted adult, such as a parent, teacher, or counselor, for support. They can help you develop a safety plan and provide you with the resources you need to manage your emotions and feelings.

Second, it's essential to consider your options for addressing the situation at school. While it's understandable that your mom has warned you against going to higher-ups, it's important to remember that there are other avenues for resolution. For example, you could speak with the school counselor or a trusted teacher about what's happened and ask for their support in resolving the situation. Additionally, you could consider involving an outside agency, such as the school board or a local civil rights organization, if you feel that your rights have been violated.

Third, it's essential to focus on self-care and maintaining a healthy routine. This can include activities such as exercise, reading, or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy. It's also important to remember that it's okay to ask for help and support from friends, family, and professionals during this time.

In summary, while the situation at your school may feel overwhelming, it's important to remember that there are resources available to you and that there are steps you can take to address the situation. By focusing on self-care, seeking support from trusted adults, and exploring your options for resolution, you can work towards finding a positive outcome and moving forward from this challenging experience.
